title: How to Make Sheet Pan Macaroni and Cheese

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 475°F (247°C).
steps.description: Generously grease an 11 by 17-inch (27.94 by 43.18-centimeter) rimmed baking sheet with 1 tablespoon (15 grams) of butter. Set the baking sheet aside when you are done.

steps.headline: Cook the macaroni.
steps.description: Boil about 4 quarts (4 liters) of salted water in a pot. Add the macaroni and cook it for about 6 minutes. Drain the macaroni when you are done, then put it back into the saucepan. You are intentionally undercooking the pasta.

steps.headline: Grate and combine the cheeses.
steps.description: Grate 12 ounces (335 grams) each of sharp and extra-sharp cheddar cheese. Set aside 2 cups (200 grams) of the cheeses for later and put everything else into the saucepan with the pasta. You can also try mild yellow Cheddar cheese and American cheese instead.

steps.headline: Toss the  together pasta mixture with some cayenne pepper and salt.
steps.description: If you have not already, add the cheese into the pasta (sans the cheese you set aside). Add some salt and pepper into the bowl, then toss everything together.

steps.headline: Spread the pasta mixture and milk across a baking sheet.
steps.description: Spread the pasta evenly across the prepared baking sheet. Next, pour the milk over the pasta. Try to make sure everything as even as possible, or the macaroni may not bake evenly.

steps.headline: Garnish it with the rest of the cheese.
steps.description: Sprinkle the reserved 2 cups (200 grams) of cheese evenly across the top of the pasta. If you want to, you can sprinkle a little bit of extra cayenne pepper on top as well.

steps.headline: Bake the pasta for about 15 minutes.
steps.description: Carefully place the baking sheet into the oven. Bake it uncovered for 15 minutes, or until the pasta turns golden-brown and crispy.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 425°F (219°C).
steps.description: Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper. Something around 11 by 17-inch (27.94 by 43.18-centimeter) would be ideal. If you don't have any parchment paper, you can generously grease the baking sheet with butter instead.

steps.headline: Boil the macaroni, drain it, then set it aside.
steps.description: Fill a large pot with about 4 quarts (4 liters) of water and bring it to a boil. Add about 1 tablespoon (17 grams) of salt, then add the macaroni. Boil it for 2 minutes less than the time specified on the box. In most cases, this will be about 5 minutes. Once it is done cooking, drain it and put it into a bowl. Do not rinse it. If you can't find any elbow macaroni, you can use another type of small pasta.

steps.headline: Prepare the roux in the same pot.
steps.description: Drain out any excess water from the pot that you cooked the macaroni in. Add 4 tablespoons (55 grams) of butter, and allow it to melt over medium-high heat. Whisk in the flour for about 1 minute. Hold off on the rest of the butter for now.

steps.headline: Add the water and milk.
steps.description: Stir the mixture with a whisk to blend everything together. Be sure to scrape the bottom of the pot so that there is no roux clinging to the bottom.

steps.headline: Add some seasoning, then cook the sauce until it thickens.
steps.description: Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce it to a simmer. Add 1¼ teaspoons of salt and a little bit of pepper. Allow the mixture to simmer for about 20 minutes or until it turns thick enough to coat the back of a spoon. Remove the pot from the burner and set it aside.

steps.headline: Combine the bread crumbs with the parsley and garlic.
steps.description: Pulse enough bread chunks in a food processor to fill 3 cups (150 grams). Add the parsley and garlic, then continue pulsing until you get a fine, grainy mixture. Use only that top ¾ of the parsley, not the entire stem.

steps.headline: Melt the rest of the butter.
steps.description: You can melt the remaining 4 tablespoons (55 grams) of butter in the microwave or in a little saucepan over the stove.

steps.headline: Combine the melted butter with the breadcrumbs along with some salt.
steps.description: Pour the melted butter over the seasoned breadcrumbs, then add ¼ teaspoon of salt. Stir everything together with a rubber spatula until evenly combined.

steps.headline: Combine the macaroni with the grated Parmigiano Reggiano and the sauce.
steps.description: Stir the grated cheese into the macaroni with a rubber spatula first. Pour the roux-based sauce over it and stir it again. Be sure to scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl often. # Spread the macaroni, mozzarella, and breadcrumbs over the prepared baking sheet. Transfer the macaroni mixture to a rimmed baking sheet. Spread it around with a rubber spatula until it is an even thickness all around. Next, sprinkle the mozzarella evenly over it, and finally the breadcrumbs.

steps.headline: Bake the macaroni for 25 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: It is ready when it turns golden-brown and the sauce is bubbly.

steps.headline: Let the macaroni rest for 10 minutes before serving it.
steps.description: Once the macaroni is done baking, take it out of the oven, and set it down on a heat-safe surface. Let it rest for 10 minutes, then serve it.

text: Making Basic Macaroni and Cheese Preheat your oven to 475°F (247°C). Generously grease an 11 by 17-inch (27.94 by 43.18-centimeter) rimmed baking sheet with 1 tablespoon (15 grams) of butter. Set the baking sheet aside when you are done. Cook the macaroni. Boil about 4 quarts (4 liters) of salted water in a pot. Add the macaroni and cook it for about 6 minutes. Drain the macaroni when you are done, then put it back into the saucepan. You are intentionally undercooking the pasta. Grate and combine the cheeses. Grate 12 ounces (335 grams) each of sharp and extra-sharp cheddar cheese. Set aside 2 cups (200 grams) of the cheeses for later and put everything else into the saucepan with the pasta. You can also try mild yellow Cheddar cheese and American cheese instead. Toss the  together pasta mixture with some cayenne pepper and salt. If you have not already, add the cheese into the pasta (sans the cheese you set aside). Add some salt and pepper into the bowl, then toss everything together. Spread the pasta mixture and milk across a baking sheet. Spread the pasta evenly across the prepared baking sheet. Next, pour the milk over the pasta. Try to make sure everything as even as possible, or the macaroni may not bake evenly. Garnish it with the rest of the cheese. Sprinkle the reserved 2 cups (200 grams) of cheese evenly across the top of the pasta. If you want to, you can sprinkle a little bit of extra cayenne pepper on top as well. Bake the pasta for about 15 minutes. Carefully place the baking sheet into the oven. Bake it uncovered for 15 minutes, or until the pasta turns golden-brown and crispy. Making Gourmet Macaroni and Cheese Preheat your oven to 425°F (219°C). Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper. Something around 11 by 17-inch (27.94 by 43.18-centimeter) would be ideal. If you don't have any parchment paper, you can generously grease the baking sheet with butter instead. Boil the macaroni, drain it, then set it aside. Fill a large pot with about 4 quarts (4 liters) of water and bring it to a boil. Add about 1 tablespoon (17 grams) of salt, then add the macaroni. Boil it for 2 minutes less than the time specified on the box. In most cases, this will be about 5 minutes. Once it is done cooking, drain it and put it into a bowl. Do not rinse it. If you can't find any elbow macaroni, you can use another type of small pasta. Prepare the roux in the same pot. Drain out any excess water from the pot that you cooked the macaroni in. Add 4 tablespoons (55 grams) of butter, and allow it to melt over medium-high heat. Whisk in the flour for about 1 minute. Hold off on the rest of the butter for now. Add the water and milk. Stir the mixture with a whisk to blend everything together. Be sure to scrape the bottom of the pot so that there is no roux clinging to the bottom. Add some seasoning, then cook the sauce until it thickens. Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce it to a simmer. Add 1¼ teaspoons of salt and a little bit of pepper. Allow the mixture to simmer for about 20 minutes or until it turns thick enough to coat the back of a spoon. Remove the pot from the burner and set it aside. Combine the bread crumbs with the parsley and garlic. Pulse enough bread chunks in a food processor to fill 3 cups (150 grams). Add the parsley and garlic, then continue pulsing until you get a fine, grainy mixture. Use only that top ¾ of the parsley, not the entire stem. Melt the rest of the butter. You can melt the remaining 4 tablespoons (55 grams) of butter in the microwave or in a little saucepan over the stove. Combine the melted butter with the breadcrumbs along with some salt. Pour the melted butter over the seasoned breadcrumbs, then add ¼ teaspoon of salt. Stir everything together with a rubber spatula until evenly combined. Combine the macaroni with the grated Parmigiano Reggiano and the sauce. Stir the grated cheese into the macaroni with a rubber spatula first. Pour the roux-based sauce over it and stir it again. Be sure to scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl often. # Spread the macaroni, mozzarella, and breadcrumbs over the prepared baking sheet. Transfer the macaroni mixture to a rimmed baking sheet. Spread it around with a rubber spatula until it is an even thickness all around. Next, sprinkle the mozzarella evenly over it, and finally the breadcrumbs. Bake the macaroni for 25 to 30 minutes. It is ready when it turns golden-brown and the sauce is bubbly. Let the macaroni rest for 10 minutes before serving it. Once the macaroni is done baking, take it out of the oven, and set it down on a heat-safe surface. Let it rest for 10 minutes, then serve it.

Making Gourmet Macaroni and Cheese Preheat your oven to 425°F (219°C).
Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper.
Something around 11 by 17-inch (27.94 by 43.18-centimeter) would be ideal.
If you don't have any parchment paper, you can generously grease the baking sheet with butter instead.
Boil the macaroni, drain it, then set it aside.
Fill a large pot with about 4 quarts (4 liters) of water and bring it to a boil.
Add about 1 tablespoon (17 grams) of salt, then add the macaroni.
Boil it for 2 minutes less than the time specified on the box.
In most cases, this will be about 5 minutes.
Once it is done cooking, drain it and put it into a bowl.
Do not rinse it.
If you can't find any elbow macaroni, you can use another type of small pasta.
Prepare the roux in the same pot.
Drain out any excess water from the pot that you cooked the macaroni in.
Add 4 tablespoons (55 grams) of butter, and allow it to melt over medium-high heat.
Whisk in the flour for about 1 minute.
Hold off on the rest of the butter for now.
Add the water and milk.
Stir the mixture with a whisk to blend everything together.
Be sure to scrape the bottom of the pot so that there is no roux clinging to the bottom.
Add some seasoning, then cook the sauce until it thickens.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce it to a simmer.
Add 1¼ teaspoons of salt and a little bit of pepper.
Allow the mixture to simmer for about 20 minutes or until it turns thick enough to coat the back of a spoon.
Remove the pot from the burner and set it aside.
Combine the bread crumbs with the parsley and garlic.
Pulse enough bread chunks in a food processor to fill 3 cups (150 grams).
Add the parsley and garlic, then continue pulsing until you get a fine, grainy mixture.
Use only that top ¾ of the parsley, not the entire stem.
Melt the rest of the butter.
You can melt the remaining 4 tablespoons (55 grams) of butter in the microwave or in a little saucepan over the stove.
Combine the melted butter with the breadcrumbs along with some salt.
Pour the melted butter over the seasoned breadcrumbs, then add ¼ teaspoon of salt.
Stir everything together with a rubber spatula until evenly combined.
Combine the macaroni with the grated Parmigiano Reggiano and the sauce.
Stir the grated cheese into the macaroni with a rubber spatula first.
Pour the roux-based sauce over it and stir it again.
Be sure to scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl often.
# Spread the macaroni, mozzarella, and breadcrumbs over the prepared baking sheet.
Transfer the macaroni mixture to a rimmed baking sheet.
Spread it around with a rubber spatula until it is an even thickness all around.
Next, sprinkle the mozzarella evenly over it, and finally the breadcrumbs.
Bake the macaroni for 25 to 30 minutes.
It is ready when it turns golden-brown and the sauce is bubbly.
Let the macaroni rest for 10 minutes before serving it.
Once the macaroni is done baking, take it out of the oven, and set it down on a heat-safe surface.
Let it rest for 10 minutes, then serve it.
